div.p:
Let it soothe you my dear
Mr. Lockhart to know that
I feel for you in this calami
ty calamity - this new loss of another
of his children - Another
Scott gone! Of all we saw
so well, so happy so prosperous
so kind at Abbotsford but
a few years ago Only Sir
Walter his son now left upon
this earth - And You - You
who have at least the satis
faction satisfaction in this deep sorrow
of knowing all you have
done for the character the
everliving memory of your
beloved father & all you
have done while yet they
lived to make his children
as happy as possible - Happy
as she was amiable and

that is saying all that can be
your wife ever appeared to
me when I had the happiness
to see her in her home with
you and her children - A
more loving more beloved
creature I never saw - I
earnestly hope that her sweet
daughter, who is so like her
may sometime, - tho though I can
never live to see it - be as
happy in her marriage as her
mother was, and may in
the mean time meantime continue to
be your consolation pride
and joy - Give my love to her
& Thank you for letting me
have her with me some hours
when I was last in London
- If ever I am there again one
of my very first objects after
seeing my own family shall
be to see her again - and
I hope to see her as well as
amiable as like her dear mother

You did all you could for
Anne Scott - That is another
soothing recollection for you
- we cannot command
events - we can - conduct
Life & Death out of our pow
er power - but how we live is ours
And common place truths
such as these in affliction
were home to the heart-

I believe you had as much
of poor Charles as you could
have while he lived in London
and have no doubt you added
to his happiness - I hope you
had no hand in sending
him out to Persia, because
I know that would be to you
a subject of regret & self reproach self-reproach
which even the consciousness
that you did it for the best,
would not in your too sensitive
mind, immediately or effect-
tually effectually still those painful feelings
I believe I had to thank
you for sending Charles Scott

to see me last Spring when I
was with my sister Wilson -
I do thank you - for his visit
left a very pleasing impression
and remembrance in my
mind of him whom we shall
see no more - And it is very
agreeable that the last impression
of a friends son should be such
- I recollect his conversation
and the characters he gave me
of his different masters in office
gave me a high notion of his
powers of observation & good
penetration into character, - And
also gratified me much by
proving his confidence in me
- his certainty that I should never
make a mischievous of impru
dent imprudent use of his frankness
It is very seldom in London life
and conversation one ever
meets with any who let you
beyond the ceremony - anti-
chamber anti-chamber of their minds - Few
minds in truth worth going farther
into - or possible to get further
into -
Yours you know
excepted -

I am glad there is a new
edition of Sir Walters life
- memoirs compressed into cheap
form - If it have the spirit
preserved in it as preserved
and heightened the spirit
of the life of Napoleon is in
your powerful compression
of Sir Walter Scotts memoirs
of Bonaparte I shall de
-light in seeing the work

But if any profane vulgar
hand has been daring to
touch and thinking only of
abridging may I never see it!

I have taken up your
Life of Sir Walter S at different
times and was never able
to lay it down without read-
ing reading on on on with insatiable interest and admiration

Who is at Abbotsford now? - or
Who takes care of it? - I ask
- without expecting my dear
Sir that you should immediate
ly immediately answer - or answer at all
if it be painful of inconvenient

to you who have so very little
time - It is to satisfy my
own feelings that I write to you
and it would pain me to
inflict upon you any pain
In consequence

Mrs. Edgeworth & (Harriet)
Mrs. Butler desire to be kindly
remembered to you - Harriet
and Fanny were shocked by
what has shocked you and
they have felt for you as I do

I have been this last month
with my sister Harriet to refit
after rather a severe bilious
illness - I have been nursed by
the kindest of friends into
perfect health again - Much
to say, just entering my 75th. year
on Jany. the 1st. next

At all seasons I wish you &
Yours happiness & health
without which, there is no happiness
div.closer:
Ever your sincerely attached
Old friend
Maria Edgeworth
